title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 5 may [1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 5 May [1868]
text: BrooklynMay th5 1868 My dear Waltit seemed quite a treat to get your letter you are the only correspondentecorrespondent i have at present they seem to all dropped off i haventhaven't had a letter from Matty in a very long while except a few lines from Jeff from cincinnattaCincinnati i haventhaven't had any word from him since his arrival home he promised he would write as soon as he arrived i told him if he was busy when he got back for mattyMatty to write because i wanted to hear but i have not got any if they have wrote to me i have not got it i think maybeemaybe they have and it has been taken and han too she promised in her letter she would neverbe so long again without writing but i suppose they all have enoughfenough to doodo without writing when one gets out of the way of writing its hard to get in it again mattyMatty was going to write to me so often she said before sheeshe went away she would write every week i got the papers to day with the letter walterWalter i like the chicagoChicago news very much i never saw one before i wish whenever you have one you would send it to me well walterWalter dear we have leved lived to see another may dayMay Day come and gone not as much moving as usual they say in the papers many has broke up houskeepinghousekeeping on the account of rents being so high i have been to look at several places georgeGeorge wants to get out of this place very much i went yesterday to look at one in carlton avenCarlton Avenue just out of fultonFulton but it was no better nor any more room than we have here and 10 dolldollars more rent a month i would rather live here than there and all the places i have been to see was something that would make it disagreabledisagreeable in some way or other) here i can doodo just as i like but of course there is some disagreabledisagreeable things but they are all as clever to me as they can beebe) georgeGeorge has lots of fun about their calling me lady whitmanWhitman the family that has come in up stairs has five children but i think she is very clean woman and the children seems orderly but they have to run up and down so there is some noise i told georgeGeorge yesterday i wasentwasn't going any where to look at any more houses but was going to wait for something to turn up i am quite lame in one of my knees i dontdon't know what makes it so it pains me considerable i suppose it must be the rheumatism settled there) sometimes i can hardly walk and then it will be better to day it feels quite bad on account perhaps of the appearance of a storm)i suppose the impeachment is dragingdragging to a close georgeGeorge thinks BingamsBingham's speech is splendid just his sentiments exactly he said at dinner time) i haventhaven't read it yet their speeches is so long i hope this will not be so lengthy as the others poor old man i wonder how he feels it will be rather sad if he is convicted for all i suppose he hasenthasn't done right i see in the papers if he leaves he will be esscortedescorted through the cityscities) walterWalter you must have congratulations from all quarters poor old alcotAlcott he must be very old seems to me) you remember waltWalt that sundaySunday morning we couldentcouldn't have him)good bie walterWalter dearmrMr. Lane told georgeGeorge they had raised JeffsJeff's salary to 6000 but i think it must be a mistakeLW Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 5 May [1868]
